thread.title: For Stiglich, Success Hasn't Changed Process
thread.title_full: For Stiglich, Success Hasn't Changed Process

title: For Stiglich, Success Hasn't Changed Process
text:
For Stiglich, Success Hasn't Changed Process 
By Zach Schneider October 15, 2015 Updated Oct 15, 2015 at 9:54 PM CDT 
Duluth, MN (NNCNOW.com) --- When University of Minnesota Duluth Brent Stiglich caught a tipped pass near the 20-yard line at Malosky Stadium, there was only one thought that ran through his head --- score. 
"Once I saw Karl Finkel blocking the quarterback," Stiglich recalled, "I knew I was going to score once I got the ball in my hands." 
Click here to subscribe to our daily newsletter. 
It was undoubtedly a nice moment for the senior, but there was no guarantee that first-ever collegiate touchdown would come. 
"It's what I've worked for ever since I got here," he said. "Watching other guys come through the program, I've just followed everyone's lead." 
That attitude paid off for Stiglich, but now, it's the young guys this season who are following him. 
"It means a lot. He tells them all the time to keep working and they'll get their time on the field," junior linebacker Beau Bates said. "You can't expect anything. You have to work your way." 
For Stiglich, that work early in his UMD career came primarily on special teams. Now, though, even as he's carved out more of a starting role, he hasn't forgotten his roots with the Bulldogs. 
"I think it's a great thing to still lead on those units and show those younger guys that stuff is still important," he said. "Just because I've earned a spot doesn't mean I can relax at any other point in my game." 
"He's a guy that's going to get in there and scrap and put everything he's got into it," defensive coordinator John Steger said. "All you've got to do is watch him cover kicks to know what kind of a football player he is." 
And it's that type of player Stiglich hopes he's helping to develop for once his time is done at UMD. 
"It's that work mentality, that Bulldog mentality," he said. "No matter where you are on that depth chart, keep working hard and keep playing."
